text: Food is fresh and right portion with reasonable price. However, the owner should not be stingy about turning on heater during the winter time or air conditioner during the summer time.

The search for decent Chinese food in the valley continues, as Jong Wah won't be our go-to place.  We started with the Popo Platter. Though we were one of just three tables there on a Saturday night around 7:30, it took nearly 30 minutes for our platter to come out. It was plated beautifully. Unfortunately, the fried shrimp had an odd texture I had to pass on, and the crab ragoon and ribs were barely lukewarm. The highlight was the egg rolls. These were clearly made in-house because the insides were crunchy. As in, not previously frozen and then defrosted mushiness. They were very good.  We ordered Kung Pao chicken and a beef and brocolli dish, plus house fried rice. The two dishes were well spiced. Often spicy dishes are just ungodly spicy where you can't taste anything else, but these actually had some flavor. It's just too bad the quality of beef was so poor you wouldn't want to eat it by itself.  The house fried rice was outstanding, with huge shrimp. We'd highly recommend the rice and eggrolls.  We also had a coupon, and our bill, with one soda, was $40. Ouch. We couldn't make heads or tails of our itemized, handwritten bill.  They do have an outdoor patio.
Gross! They closed due to failing health inspection numerous times. Cockroach infestation! Check public health site. They post to public. Jong Blahhhh!

For about $5, (lunch menu), you can get a LOT of food here. I got Chow Mein, Sweet & Sour Pork, and Black Pepper Chicken, and it was over loaded in the to-go styrofoam box. When I got it to go and got home, I looked at everything and I felt like I ripped them off. Pretty good classic Chinese food.   The only thing is that the music that they play in that place is obviously played over and over again very frequently (even though it's instrumental) and started driving me nuts. This happened the second time we dined here, we actually asked them to please turn it down or to change it altogether since it was annoying. Their curry was a bit bland and funny tasting but I liked their classic fried rice and chow mein dishes. Dig in!

Wife and I haven't been to this restaurant for over 10+ years --- as I remember, it was because the food was mediocre and there are better Cantonese restaurants in the area.  But we had a restaurant.com certificate -- $25 worth of food for $3.00 so we decided to try again.  I cannot figure out how this restaurant.com thing works for the establishments.....maybe hoping for repeat business?  But what if you keep buying the coupons?  Oh well, it must work or restaurants wouldn't participate now, would they?  Well this trip the restaurant probably did not lose money on us.  We spent over $60 on food and a couple of beers.  With tax and tip the bill was slightly over $80 and with the $25 coupon, I paid $55.  We had half a roast duck (mediocre-dry and not crispy); mapo tofu (good); salt and pepper shrimps and salt and pepper pork chops (both dishes prepared in the same fashion-good sized serving but the batter was a little thick and chewy); Hong Kong style pork chow mein (this was very good); and finally Mongolian beef (average at best-spice level was low and not very tasty).  The dishes were all probably priced at least $1.00 each higher than other comparable places.  So our conclusion is that with the coupon, the value is OK.  But without the coupon, it is not worth the price for the quality of the food.  In fact, both my wife and I agreed that we would rather pay the price to get better quality food.  Don't get me wrong, this place is not bad; just not very good.  Lastly, we agree with one other yelper -- the place was very cold.  They need to up the heating in the place.

Don't judge this place by the restaurant's exterior! Jong Wang is excellent. Went there just last Wed. with my family and the food was fresh and delicious. A coworker of my mother's recommended the place and it was a good one! We'll be back. I recommend the Szechuan Garlic chicken.
Good Chinese food, fast and very cheap. Definitely recommended!
This was my favorite Chinese restaurant, and unfortunately they closed on October 15, 2013.  They are no longer in business.

I give no stars! It should have been a sign to me when we were the only ones there! some other guest came in while we were there, but only 2 other couples. PuPu Plater was skimpy, no spare ribs, and the satay beef was very tough. Egg Rolls had tough cabbage in them, they did however have large pieces of shrimp in them, although the shrimp in every dish we had didn't taste fresh. The sizzling Rice soup was made with old tasting rice. I had Cashew chicken which should have been called celery chicken, cause that's mostly what was there. Plus the celery was hard and stringy. We order combo fried rice, it was good, but I didn't understand why I didn't get steamed rice with our two entres. Over all Resturant.com should remove them from their listing! thumbs down. Slow service too!

Nice local place, very fast service, friendly, with decent food. Wonton and Hot-and-Sour soup are very good. Crispy orange beef  is tasty, General Tso's chicken is very good, and the fried rice is flavorful with lots of meat. Not gourmet food, but an excellent place for some quick tasty Chinese food.

First of all, let me assure you that we actually ate our dinner here (7/4/11) last night.  Yelp doesn't allow us to check-in online because the map shows the wrong location!!!  It's at the SW corner of Guadalupe & Alma School in case you are wondering.  The reason I'm so inclined to write this review so quickly is to warn people about this place.  The wife and her stomach has been suffering badly (if you know what I mean) since last night.  She has to miss work today because of that.  We ordered 3 dishes:  seafood combination, deep fried special tofu and Peking style pork chop.   We narrowed the culprit to be in the $16 seafood dish - which is actually a quick stir fry of seafood (scallops, shrimp, fish, mussels, green peppers, onions) in a spicy black bean sauce.  The menu item description includes a lobster tail but it's nowhere to be found.   Bottomline: it has to be a case of bad mussels on shells since she was the only one who ate them in our party of 3.  I hope this helps out anyone who is maybe thinking of trying this place.  Or you can just head out instead to Aloha Kitchen around the corner  for some good Hawaiian food.   Count this one to experience.
This is the best Chinese food I have eaten for a very long time! I had a restaurant com certificate so I ended up getting 4 main courses and 1 assorted appetizer course. Everything was done perfect.
